comment.bubble:
Most coding languages allow you to leave comments in your code. In CSS you can create a comment by starting it with /* and ending with */. Code are instructions, it's how you tell the browser what you want it to display, but browsers ignore comments. Comments are for people, not machines.

Coders use them for all sorts of reasons, most often for leaving notes explaining how the code works (future you will thank you for that). It's also a great way to credit any code snippets you've copy+pasted from somewhere else. They can also be used to "comment out" code, so that the browser ignores it temporarily without having to remove it.

The shortcut key CTRL+/ (control forward-slash), or CMD+/ (command forward-slash) on Mac, can be used to comment out lines of code.

clip-path.bubble: The clip-path property can be used to "clip" or "mask" certain regions of an element. It's a great way of transforming elements into all sorts of different shapes. Learn more about it at css-tricks.com. We're working on widgets that make it easier to use properties like these, but in the meantime checkout this great clip-path generator!
